[[Image:Naked short.png|thumb|upright=1.5|Schematic representation of naked short selling in two steps. The short seller sells shares without owning them. He then purchases and delivers the shares for a different market price. If the short seller cannot afford the shares in the second step, or the shares are not available, a "[[fail to deliver]]" results.]]
'''Naked short selling''', or '''naked shorting''', is the practice of [[Short (finance)|short-selling]] a [[financial instrument|tradable asset of any kind]] without first [[Securities lending|borrowing the security]] or ensuring that the security can be borrowed, as is conventionally done in a short sale. When the seller does not obtain the shares within the required time frame, the result is known as a "[[failure to deliver]]". The transaction generally remains open until the shares are acquired by the seller, or the seller's broker settles the trade.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://law.bepress.com/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1917&context=expresso |title=Future-Priced Convertible Securities & The Outlook For "Death-Spiral" Securities-Fraud Litigation |first=Zachary T |last=Knepper |work=Bepress Legal Repository |publisher=Berkeley Electronic Press |year=2004 |pages=15 |format=pdf}}</ref>
Short selling is used to anticipate a price fall, but exposes the seller to the risk of a price rise.
In 2008, the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]] banned what it called "abusive naked short selling"<ref name=2009-172 /> in the United States, as well as some other jurisdictions, as a method of driving down share prices. Failing to deliver shares is legal under certain circumstances, and naked short selling is not ''per se'' illegal.<ref name="Schapiro testimony">{{cite web|url=http://fcic-static.law.stanford.edu/cdn_media/fcic-docs/2010-01-14%20Mary%20Schapiro%20Written%20Testimony.pdf|title=Testimony of Mary Schapiro, Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission|publisher=Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission|date=Jan 14, 2010|page=22|accessdate=16 April 2011}}</ref><ref name=KeyPoints/><ref name=WSJ_July2007>{{cite news|accessdate= |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB118359867562957720 |title=Blame the 'Stock Vault'? |author1=Emshwiller, John R. |author2=Kara Scannell |lastauthoramp=yes |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=July 5, 2007}}</ref> In the United States, naked short selling is covered by various SEC regulations which prohibit the practice.<ref name="Ellis"> {{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2008/09/17/news/companies/sec_short_selling/index.htm |title=SEC puts 'naked' short sellers on notice |publisher=www.cnn.com |date=September 17, 2008 |accessdate=2008-09-23 |last=Ellis |first=David }} </ref>
Critics, including [[Overstock.com]]'s [[Patrick M. Byrne]], have advocated for stricter regulations against naked short selling. In 2005, "[[Regulation SHO]]" was enacted; requiring that broker-dealers have grounds to believe that shares will be available for a given stock transaction, and requiring that delivery take place within a limited time period.<ref name=KeyPoints> {{Cite web |title=Key Points About Regulation SHO |publisher=Securities and Exchange Commission |date=April 11, 2005 |url=https://www.sec.gov/spotlight/keyregshoissues.htm |accessdate=2008-10-19}} </ref><ref name=secfaq>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sec.gov/divisions/marketreg/mrfaqregsho1204.htm |title=Division of Market Regulation: Responses to Frequently Asked Questions Concerning Regulation SHO |publisher=Securities and Exchange Commission |accessdate=2008-10-19 }} </ref>
According to data compiled by the SEC and Bloomberg, naked short selling of the shares of Lehman Brothers may have played a role in the North American markets crisis of 2008.<ref>{{cite news |title=Naked short sales hint fraud in bringing down Lehman |url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/naked-short-sales-hint-fraud-in-bringing-down-lehman-109032000046_1.html |work=Business Standard India |date=20 March 2009}}</ref>
As part of its response to the crisis, the SEC issued a temporary order restricting short-selling in the shares of 19 financial firms deemed systemically important, by reinforcing the penalties for failing to deliver the shares in time.<ref> [http://www.economist.com/finance/PrinterFriendly.cfm?story_id=11951246 Searching for the naked truth], [[The Economist]], Aug 17, 2008</ref> Effective September 18, 2008, amid claims that aggressive short selling had played a role in the failure of financial giant [[Lehman Brothers]], the SEC extended and expanded the rules to remove exceptions and to cover all companies, including [[market maker]]s.<ref name=2009-172>{{citation |title= SEC Takes Steps to Curtail Abusive Short Sales and Increase Market Transparency |publisher= Securities and Exchange Commission |date= July 27, 2009 |url= https://www.sec.gov/news/press/2009/2009-172.htm }}</ref><ref name="WaPo"> {{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/09/17/AR2008091703631.html |title=New SEC Rules Target 'Naked' Short-Selling |date=September 18, 2008 |last=Gordon |first=Marcy |publisher=Associated Press }} </ref>
A 2014 study by researchers at the University at Buffalo, published in the Journal of Financial Economics, found no evidence that failure to deliver stock "caused price distortions or the failure of financial firms during the 2008 financial crisis" and that "greater FTDs lead to higher liquidity and pricing efficiency, and their impact is similar to our estimate of delivered short sales."<ref name="sciencedirect.com">{{cite journal | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304405X14001597 | doi=10.1016/j.jfineco.2014.07.012 | volume=114 | title=Fails-to-deliver, short selling, and market quality | journal=Journal of Financial Economics | pages=493–516}}</ref>
Some commentators have contended that despite regulations, naked shorting is widespread and that the SEC regulations are poorly enforced. Its critics have contended that the practice is susceptible to abuse, can be damaging to targeted companies struggling to raise capital, and has led to numerous bankruptcies.<ref name="Ellis"/><ref name="Watch Out, They Bite!">{{cite web|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1126706-3,00.html|title=Watch Out, They Bite!|first=Daniel|last=Kadlec|date=9 November 2005|publisher=|via=www.time.com}}</ref> However, other commentators have said that the naked shorting issue is a "devil theory",<ref name='Bankinvestors'/> not a ''bona fide'' market issue and a waste of regulatory resources.<ref name='Donlan'/>
==Description==
=== "Normal" shorting ===
{{Main|Short (finance)}} Short selling is a form of [[speculation]] that allows a [[trader (finance)|trader]] to take a "[[position (finance)|negative position]]" in a stock of a company. Such a trader first "[[Securities lending|borrows]]" shares of that stock from their owner (the lender), typically via a [[bank]] or a [[prime broker]] under the condition that he will return it on demand. Next, the trader sells the borrowed shares and delivers them to the buyer who becomes their new owner. The buyer is typically unaware that the shares have been sold short: his transaction with the trader proceeds just as if the trader owned rather than borrowed the shares. Some time later, the trader closes his short position by purchasing the same number of shares in the market and returning them to the lender.
The trader's profit is the difference between the sale price and the purchase price of the shares. In contrast to "going long" where sale succeeds the purchase, short sale precedes the purchase. Because the seller/borrower is generally required to make a cash deposit equivalent to the sale proceeds, it offers the lender some security.
===Naked shorts in the United States===
Naked short selling is a case of short selling without first arranging a borrow. If the stock is in short supply, finding shares to borrow can be difficult. The seller may also decide not to borrow the shares, in some cases because lenders are not available, or because the costs of lending are too high. When shares are not borrowed within the clearing time period and the short-seller does not tender shares to the buyer, the trade is considered to have "[[failure to deliver|failed to deliver]]."<ref name="fool"> {{Cite web |url=http://www.fool.com/investing/high-growth/2005/03/24/the-naked-truth-on-illegal-shorting.aspx |title=The Naked Truth on Illegal Shorting |publisher=www.fool.com |accessdate=2008-03-12 }} </ref> Nevertheless, the trade will continue to sit open or the buyer may be credited the shares by the [[Depository Trust & Clearing Corporation|DTCC]] until the short-seller either closes out the position or borrows the shares.<ref name="WSJ_July2007"/>
It is difficult to measure how often naked short selling occurs. Fails to deliver are not necessarily indicative of naked shorting, and can result from both "long" transactions (stock purchases) and short sales.<ref name=KeyPoints/><ref name='SECFails'/> Naked shorting can be invisible in a liquid market, as long as the short sale is eventually delivered to the buyer. However, if the covers are impossible to find, the trades fail. Fail reports are published regularly by the SEC,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/foia/docs/failsdata.htm|title=SEC.gov - Frequently Requested FOIA Document: Fails-to-Deliver Data|publisher=}}</ref> and a sudden rise in the number of fails-to-deliver will alert the SEC to the possibility of naked short selling. In some recent cases, it was claimed that the daily activity was larger than all of the available shares, which would normally be unlikely.<ref name=fool/>
====Extent of naked shorting====
The reasons for naked shorting, and the extent of it, had been disputed for several years before the SEC's 2008 action to prohibit the practice. What is generally recognized is that naked [[shorting]] tends to happen when shares are difficult to borrow. Studies have shown that naked [[short selling]] also increases with the cost of borrowing {{Citation needed|date=May 2012}}.
In recent years,{{when|date=December 2014}} a number of companies{{which|date=December 2014}} have been accused{{by whom|date=January 2012}} of using naked shorts in aggressive efforts to drive down share prices, sometimes with no intention of ever delivering the shares.<ref name=fool/> These claims argue that, at least in theory, the practice allows an unlimited number of shares to be sold short. A ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' editorial in July 2008 said that naked short selling "enables speculators to drive down a company's stock by offering an overwhelming number of shares for sale."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/classified/realestate/news/la-ed-sec17-2008jul17,0,5572972.story |title=The SEC finally steps in; As other regulators hustle to address the economy, the Securities and Exchange Commission needs to better enforce laws already on its books |date=July 17, 2008 |work=Los Angeles Times }}</ref>
The SEC has stated that naked shorting is sometimes falsely asserted as a reason for a share price decline, when, often, "the price decrease is a result of the company's poor financial situation rather than the reasons provided by the [[insider]]s or promoters."<ref name=KeyPoints/>
Before 2008, regulators had generally downplayed the extent of naked shorting in the US. At a [[North American Securities Administrators Association]] (NASAA) conference on naked short selling in November 2005, an official of the [[New York Stock Exchange]] stated that NYSE had not found evidence of widespread naked short selling. In 2006, an official of the SEC said that "While there may be instances of abusive short selling, 99% of all trades in dollar value settle on time without incident."<ref name="dtcc2006sho"> {{Cite web |url=http://www.dtcc.com/news/press/releases/2006/sho.php |title=Regulators Say REG SHO is Working |publisher=Depository Trust and Clearing Corporation (DTCC) |date=January 24, 2006 |accessdate=2008-03-12 }} </ref> Of all those that do not, 85% are resolved within 10 business days and 90% within 20.<ref name="dtcc2006sho"/> That means that about 1% of shares that change hands daily, or about $1 billion per day, are subject to delivery failures,<ref name=WSJ_July2007/> although the SEC has stated that "fails-to-deliver can occur for a number of reasons on both long and short sales," and accordingly that they do not necessarily indicate naked short selling.<ref name=KeyPoints/><ref name='SECFails'> {{Cite web |url=https://www.sec.gov/foia/docs/failsdata.htm |title=Fails-to-Deliver Data |publisher=www.sec.gov |accessdate=2008-03-12 }} </ref>
In 2008, SEC chairman [[Christopher Cox]] said that the SEC "has zero tolerance for abusive naked short-selling" while implementing new regulations to prohibit the practice, culminating in the September 2008 action following the failures of [[Bear Stearns]] and [[Lehman Brothers]] amidst speculation that naked short selling had played a contributory role.<ref name="WaPo"/><ref>[https://www.sec.gov/news/press/2008/2008-204.htm "SEC Issues New Rules to Protect Investors Against Naked Short Selling Abuses"], Press release, Securities and Exchange Commission, September 17, 2008</ref> Cox said that "the rule would be designed to ensure transparency in short-selling in general, beyond the practice of naked short-selling."<ref name="WaPo" />
====Claimed effects of naked shorting==== {{quotation|The SEC is committed to maintaining orderly securities markets. The abusive practice of naked short selling is far different from ordinary short selling, which is a healthy and necessary part of a free market. Our agency’s rules are highly supportive of short selling, which can help quickly transmit price signals in response to negative information or prospects for a company. Short selling helps prevent “irrational exuberance” and bubbles. But when someone fails to borrow and deliver the securities needed to make good on a short position, after failing even to determine that they can be borrowed, that is not contributing to an orderly market — it is undermining it. And in the context of a potential “distort and short” campaign aimed at an otherwise sound financial institution, this kind of manipulative activity can have drastic consequences.|Speech by SEC chairman<ref>{{cite web|title=Naked Short Selling Is One Problem a Slumping Market Shouldn't Have|url=https://www.sec.gov/news/speech/2008/spch071808cc.htm|accessdate=23 July 2012}}</ref>}}
As with the prevalence of naked shorting, the effects are contested. The SEC has stated that the practice can be beneficial in enhancing liquidity in difficult-to-borrow shares, while others have suggested that it adds efficiency to the securities lending market. Critics of the practice argue that it is often used for [[market manipulation]], that it can damage companies and even that it threatens the broader markets.
One complaint about naked shorting from targeted companies is that the practice dilutes a company's shares for as long as unsettled short sales sit open on the books. This has been alleged to create "phantom" or "counterfeit" shares, sometimes going from trade to trade without connection to any physical shares, and artificially depressing the share price. However, the SEC has disclaimed the existence of counterfeit shares and stated that naked short selling would not increase a company's outstanding shares.<ref name=secfaq/> Short seller [[David Rocker]] contended that failure to deliver securities "can be done for manipulative purposes to create the impression that the stock is a tight borrow," although he said that this should be seen as a failure to deliver "longs" rather than "shorts."<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.thestreet.com/story/10240003/1/naked-truth-dressed-to-baffle.html |title=Naked Truth Dressed to Baffle |date=August 29, 2005 |publisher=www.thestreet.com |accessdate=2008-04-03 }} </ref>
[[Robert J. Shapiro]], former undersecretary of commerce for economic affairs, and a consultant to a law firm suing over naked shorting,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/naked-short-selling-center-looming/story.aspx?guid={4B3FE0D6-1EFF-4986-83B3-54F21475CA1C} |title='Naked' short selling is center of looming legal battle; Companies on the defensive seize upon an aggressive form of shorting |author=Alistair Barr |publisher=MarketWatch |date=June 14, 2006 }}</ref> has claimed that naked short selling has cost investors $100 billion and driven 1,000 companies into the ground.<ref name="Watch Out, They Bite!"/>
[[Richard Fuld]], the former CEO of the financial firm Lehman Brothers, during hearings on the bankruptcy filing by Lehman Brothers and bailout of AIG before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform alleged that a host of factors including a crisis of confidence and naked short selling attacks followed by false rumors contributed to the collapse of both Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers.<ref>[http://oversight.house.gov/story.asp?ID=2176 Committee to Hold Hearings on Collapse of Lehman Brothers and AIG], October 03, 2008 [http://oversight.house.gov/documents/20081006125839.pdf testimony of Richard Fuld] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826083809/http://oversight.house.gov/documents/20081006125839.pdf |date=2009-08-26 }}</ref> Fuld had been obsessed with short sellers and had even demoted those Lehman executives that dealt with them; he claimed that the short sellers and the rumour mongers had brought down Lehman, although he had no evidence of it.<ref name=vendetta /> Upon the examination of the issue of whether "naked short selling" was in any way a cause of the collapse of Bear Stearns or Lehman, securities experts reached the conclusion that the alleged "naked short sales" occurred after the collapse and therefore played no role in it. House committee Chairman Henry Waxman said the committee received thousands of pages of internal documents from Lehman and these documents portray a company in which there was “no accountability for failure".<ref name=vendetta>{{citation |title= Dick Fuld’s Vendetta Against Short-Sellers—and Goldman Sachs |work= Deal Journal (Wall Street Journal Blogs) |author= Heidi N. Moore |date=2008-10-07 | url= https://blogs.wsj.com/deals/2008/10/07/dick-fulds-vendetta-against-short-sellers-and-goldman-sachs/}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://money.cnn.com/2008/10/06/news/companies/lehman_hearing/?postversion=2008100612 | work=CNN | title=Fuld blames 'crisis of confidence' | date=October 6, 2008 | accessdate=May 19, 2010 | first1=Aaron | last1=Smith}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.hereisthecity.com/news/business_news/8317.cntns|title=HITC Business - News|publisher=}}</ref> In July 2008, U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Christopher Cox said there was no "unbridled naked short selling in financial issues."<ref name='Cox-preventive'/>
==Regulations in the United States==
===Securities Exchange Act of 1934=== The [[Securities Exchange Act of 1934]] stipulates a settlement period up to two business days before a stock needs to be delivered, generally referred to as "[[T+2]] delivery."
===Regulation SHO=== The SEC enacted Regulation SHO in January 2005 to target abusive naked short selling by reducing [[failure to deliver (finance)|failure to deliver]] securities, and by limiting the time in which a broker can permit failures to deliver.<ref name="keypoints">[https://www.sec.gov/spotlight/keyregshoissues.htm "Key Points About Regulation SHO"], Security and Exchange Commission</ref> In addressing the first, it stated that a broker or dealer may not accept a short sale order without having first borrowed or identified the stock being sold.<ref name="law.uc.edu">{{Cite web|url=http://www.law.uc.edu/CCL/regSHO/rule203.html|title=Securities Lawyer's Deskbook, Rule 203 |author=University of Cincinnati College of Law}}</ref> The rule had the following exemptions: #Broker or dealer accepting a short sale order from another registered broker or dealer #Bona fide [[Market maker|market making]] #Broker-dealer effecting a sale on behalf of a customer that is deemed to own the security pursuant to Rule 200<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.law.uc.edu/CCL/regSHO/rule200.html |title=Securities Lawyer's Deskbook, Rule 200 |author=University of Cincinnati College of Law}}</ref> through no fault of the customer or the broker-dealer.<ref name="law.uc.edu"/>
To reduce the duration for which fails to deliver are permitted to sit open, the regulation requires broker-dealers to close out open fail-to-deliver positions in threshold securities that have persisted for 13 consecutive settlement days.<ref name="keypoints"/> The SEC, in describing Regulation SHO, stated that failures to deliver shares that persist for an extended period of time "may result in large delivery obligations where stock settlement occurs."<ref name="keypoints"/>
Regulation SHO also created the "Threshold Security List", which reported any stock where more than 0.5% of a company's total outstanding shares failed delivery for five consecutive days. A number of companies have appeared on the list, including [[Krispy Kreme]], [[Martha Stewart Omnimedia]] and [[Delta Air Lines]]. The [[Motley Fool]], an investment website, observes that "when a stock appears on this list, it is like a red flag waving, stating 'something is wrong here!'"<ref name=fool/> However, the SEC clarified that appearance on the threshold list "does not necessarily mean that there has been abusive naked short selling or any impermissible trading in the stock."<ref name="keypoints"/>
In July 2006, the SEC proposed to amend Regulation SHO, to further reduce failures to deliver securities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/rules/proposed/2006/34-54154.pdf|format=PDF|author=United States Securities and Exchange Commission|title=Proposed SEC 17 CFR PART 242 (Release No. 34-54154; File No. S7-12-06) RIN 3235-AJ57 Amendments to Regulation SHO}}</ref> SEC Chairman [[Christopher Cox]] referred to "the serious problem of abusive naked short sales, which can be used as a tool to drive down a company's stock price" and that the SEC is "concerned about the persistent failures to deliver in the market for some securities that may be due to loopholes in Regulation SHO".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/news/speech/2006/spch071206cc2.htm|title=Opening Statements at the US Securities and Exchange Commission Open Meeting|date=July 12, 2006|author=Christopher Cox}}</ref>
===Developments, 2007 to the present=== In June 2007, the SEC voted to remove the [[grandfather clause|grandfather provision]] that allowed fails-to-deliver that existed before Reg SHO to be exempt from Reg SHO. SEC Chairman Christopher Cox called naked short selling "a fraud that the commission is bound to prevent and to punish." The SEC also said it was considering removing an exemption from the rule for options [[market maker]]s.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/14/business/14sec.html?ref=business |title=S.E.C. Ends Decades-Old Price Limits on Short Selling |author=Floyd Norris |work=The New York Times |date=June 14, 2007}}</ref> Removal of the grandfather provision and naked shorting restrictions generally have been endorsed by the [[U.S. Chamber of Commerce]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasdaq.com/|title=NASDAQ's Homepage for Retail Investors|publisher=}}</ref>
In March 2008, SEC Chairman [[Christopher Cox]] gave a speech entitled the "'Naked' Short Selling Anti-Fraud Rule," in which he announced new SEC efforts to combat naked short selling.<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/news/speech/2008/video0030408cc_short.wmv Video of [[Christopher Cox]]], March 2008</ref> Under the proposal, the SEC would create an antifraud rule targeting those who knowingly deceive brokers about having located securities before engaging in short sales, and who fail to deliver the securities by the delivery date. Cox said the proposal would address concerns about short-selling abuses, particularly in the market for [[market capitalization|small-cap stocks]]. Even with the regulation in place, the SEC received hundreds of complaints in 2007 about alleged abuses involving short sales. The SEC estimated that about 1% of shares that changed hands daily, about $1 billion, were subject to delivery failures. SEC Commissioners Paul Atkins and Kathleen Casey expressed support for the crackdown.<ref>Judith A. Burns, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120468499197912561?mod=googlenews_wsj "SEC Proposes Teeth for Short-Selling Rules"], ''Wall Street Journal'', March 5, 2008</ref><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/etfNews/idUSN0446331920080304 "SEC proposes tougher 'naked' short selling rules"], March 4, 2008, ''Reuters''</ref>
In mid-July 2008, the SEC announced emergency actions to limit the naked short selling of [[government sponsored enterprise]]s (GSEs), such as [[Fannie Mae]] and [[Freddie Mac]], in an effort to limit market volatility of financial stocks.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aQRBietUNVyw|last=Westbrook|first=Jesse|title=SEC to Limit Short Sales of Fannie, Freddie, Brokers|date=July 15, 2008|accessdate=2008-07-15|publisher=Bloomberg.com}}</ref> But even with respect to those stocks the SEC soon thereafter announced there would be an exception with regard to market makers.<ref name="Ivy">Ivy Schmerken, [http://www.wallstreetandtech.com/advancedtrading/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=209101993&cid=RSSfeed_WST_News "SEC Short Sale Rule Could Create a Bubble in Financial Stocks"], ''Wall Street & Technology'', July 20, 2008</ref> SEC Chairman Cox noted that the emergency order was "not a response to unbridled naked short selling in financial issues", saying that "that has not occurred". Cox said, "rather it is intended as a preventative step to help restore market confidence at a time when it is sorely needed."<ref name='Cox-preventive'>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/news/speech/2008/spch071808cc.htm |title=Public Statement by SEC Chairman: Naked Short Selling Is One Problem a Slumping Market Shouldn't Have |accessdate=2009-08-23 |last=Cox |first=Christopher |date=2008-07-18 |publisher=Securities and Exchange Commission }}</ref> Analysts warned of the potential for the creation of price bubbles.<ref name="Ivy"/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601039&refer=columnist_antilla&sid=al7ADyiLbmAE |title=Short Sellers in Stock Cop's Sights |author=Susan Antilla |date=August 1, 2008 |work=Bloomberg }}</ref>
The emergency actions rule expired August 12, 2008.<ref name="nyex">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/13/business/economy/13place.html |title=Did It Help to Curb Short Sales? |author=Floyd Norris |date=August 12, 2008 |work=New York Times }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/markets/2008-08-12-sec-short-selling-ban_N.htm |title=SEC's ban on short-selling Fannie, Freddie ends |date=August 13, 2008 |author=Marcy Gordon |publisher=Associated Press }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-moneyblog13-2008aug13,0,2983613.story |title=Short sellers pare bets on financials |author=Tom Petruno |date=August 13, 2008 |work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/markets/2008-08-13-naked-short-sales_N.htm |title=Financial stocks suffer after protection ends |date=August 13, 2008 |author=Matt Krantz |work=USA Today }}</ref> However, on September 17, 2008, the SEC issued new, more extensive rules against naked shorting, making "it crystal clear that the SEC has zero tolerance for abusive naked short selling". Among the new rules is that market makers are no longer given an exception. As a result, options market makers will be treated in the same way as all other market participants, and effectively will be banned from naked short selling.<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/news/press/2008/2008-204.htm "SEC Issues New Rules to Protect Investors Against Naked Short Selling Abuses"], Securities and Exchange Commission, September 17, 2008</ref>
On November 4, 2008, voters in South Dakota considered a ballot initiative, "The South Dakota Small Investor Protection Act", to end naked short selling in that state. The Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association of Washington and New York said they would take legal action if the measure passed.<ref>Sara Hansard, [http://www.investmentnews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20081102/REG/311039962/1027/HEDGEFUNDS "SIFMA to sue if short-sale vote wins; Naked short selling on South Dakota ballot], ''InvestmentNews'', November 2, 2008</ref> The voters defeated the initiative.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.investmentnews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20081105/REG/811059981 |title= Naked short-selling ban nixed in S. Dakota |author=Aaron Siegel |date=November 5, 2008 |work=InvestmentNews}}</ref>
In July 2009, the SEC, under what the Wall Street Journal described as "intense political pressure," made permanent an interim rule that obliges brokerages to promptly buy or borrow securities when executing a short sale.<ref name='WSJ7-27'>{{cite news | first=Sarah N. | last=Lynch | title=SEC to Limit 'Naked' Short-Selling | date=2009-07-27 | publisher= | url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB124871727822084391 | work =The Wall Street Journal | pages = | accessdate = 2009-07-27 | language = }}</ref> The SEC said that since the fall of 2008, abusive naked short selling had been reduced by 50%, and the number of threshold list securities (equity securities with too many "fails to deliver") declined from 582 in July 2008 to 63 in March 2009.<ref name='SEC7-09'>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/news/press/2009/2009-172.htm |title=SEC Takes Steps to Curtail Abusive Short Sales and Increase Market Transparency |accessdate=2009-07-28 |date=2009-07-24 |work=Securities and Exchange Commission }}</ref><ref name='BBC'>{{cite news|first=BBC |last=News |title=US rules on abusive short selling |work=bbc.co.uk |pages= |accessdate=2009-07-27 |publisher= |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/8171667.stm; |language= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090731163151/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/8171667.stm |archivedate=July 31, 2009 }}</ref>
In January 2010, Mary Schapiro, chairperson of the SEC, testified before the U.S. Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission that fails to deliver in equity securities had declined 63.4 percent, while persistent and large fails had declined 80.5 percent.<ref name="Schapiro testimony"/>
==Regulations outside of the United States== Several international exchanges have either partially or fully restricted the practice of naked short selling of shares. They include Australia's [[Australian Securities Exchange]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.smh.com.au/business/asx-ban-on-short-selling-is-indefinite-20081003-4t16.html |title=ASX ban on short selling is indefinite |date=October 3, 2008 |work=Sydney Morning Herald |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005040752/http://news.smh.com.au/business/asx-ban-on-short-selling-is-indefinite-20081003-4t16.html |archivedate=October 5, 2008 |df= }}</ref> India's [[Securities and Exchange Board of India|Securities and Exchange Board]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.livemint.com/2008/10/23001508/Sebi-bans-overseas-shortselli.html |title=Sebi bans overseas short-selling |date=October 28, 2008 |work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> the Netherlands's [[Euronext Amsterdam]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrc.nl/international/article1993052.ece/Dutch_invented_short_selling_in_1609 |title=Dutch invented short selling in 1609 |date=2008-09-22 |accessdate=2015-01-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202083735/http://www.nrc.nl/international/article1993052.ece/Dutch_invented_short_selling_in_1609 |archivedate=2010-12-02 |df= }}</ref> Japan's [[Tokyo Stock Exchange]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB122518367230175569?mod=googlenews_wsj |title=Japan Cracks Down on Naked Short Selling |date=October 28, 2008 |work=Wall Street Journal | first1=Takashi | last1=Nakamichi | first2=Ayai | last2=Tomisawa}}</ref> and Switzerland's [[SWX Swiss Exchange]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/09/19/business/sell.php |title=More countries put bans on short selling |publisher = Reuters |date = September 19, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/09/21/business/short.php |title=More regulators move to curb short-selling |author=Matthew Saltmarsh |date=September 21, 2008 }}</ref> Also Spain's securities regulator [[Comisión Nacional del Mercado de Valores|CNMV]].<ref>{{citation |title= Short selling restrictions and disclosure obligations in Spain |author= [[Ashurst (law firm)|Ashurst]] Madrid |date= September–October 2008 |url= http://www.ashurst.com/doc.aspx?id_Resource=2368 }} (restrictions adopted on 22 September 2008)</ref>
In March 2007, the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI), which disallowed short sales altogether in 2001 as a result of the [[Ketan Parekh]] affair, reintroduced short selling under regulations similar to those developed in the United States. In conjunction with this rule change, SEBI outlawed all naked short selling.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/2007/12/24/stories/2007122451310200.htm |title=What is short selling? |work=The Hindu Business Line |date=December 23, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/fe_full_story.php?content_id=158750 |title=Sebi allows all to sell short |work=The Financial Express |date=March 22, 2007}}</ref>
Japan's naked shorting ban started on November 4, 2008, and was originally scheduled to run until July 2009, but was extended through October of that year.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601080&sid=ay5tFHVU_E8M&refer=asia |title=TCI Cuts $1 Billion of Japanese Short Stock Positions |date=May 18, 2009 |author=Tomoko Yamazaki |publisher=Bloomberg }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601101&sid=aAsRVcwKKQxc | work=Bloomberg | title=Japan Extends Curbs on Short-Selling Until Oct. 31 (Correct) | date=July 24, 2009}}</ref> Japan's [[Ministry of Finance (Japan)|Finance]] [[Minister of Finance (Japan)|Minister]], [[Shōichi Nakagawa]] stated, "We decided (to move up the short-selling ban) as we thought it could be dangerous for the Tokyo stock market if we do not take action immediately." Nakagawa added that Japan's [[Financial Services Agency]] would be teaming with the [[Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission]] and Tokyo Stock Exchange to investigate past violations of Japanese regulations on stock short-selling. The ban was subsequently extended through October 2010.<ref>"Japan to extend naked short selling ban to Oct." Reuters, July 26, 2010, https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTOE66P06G20100726</ref>
The [[Singapore Exchange]] started to penalize naked short sales with an interim measure in September, 2008. These initial penalties started at $100 per day. In November, they announced plans to increase the fines for failing to complete trades. The new penalties would penalize traders who fail to cover their positions, starting at $1,000 per day. There would also be fines for brokerages who fail to use the exchange's buying-in market to cover their positions, starting at $5,000 per day. The Singapore exchange had stated that the failure to deliver shares inherent in naked short sales threatened market orderliness.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://business.asiaone.com/Business/News/My%2BMoney/Story/A1Story20081114-100716.html |title=SGX to build up penalties for 'naked' short-selling |author=Goh Eng Yeow |date=November 16, 2008 |work=The Straits Times }}</ref>
On May 18, 2010, the German Minister of Finance announced that naked short sales of euro-denominated government bonds, credit default swaps based on those bonds, and shares in Germany's ten leading financial institutions will be prohibited. This ban went into effect that night and was set to expire on March 31, 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE64H61J20100518|title=Germany bans naked short-selling|date=May 18, 2010|author1=Erik Kirschbaum |author2=Andrew Torchia |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher=Reuters}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/10124179.stm|title=Euro drops to new four-year low against US dollar|author=BBC News|date=May 18, 2010|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> On May 28, German financial market regulator BaFin announced that this ban would be permanent.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE64R2PF20100528|title=Germany to permanently ban some short selling: Bafin'|author=Reuters|date=May 28, 2010|publisher=Reuters}}</ref> The ban is effective July 27, 2010.<ref>Naked Short-Selling Ban Coming into Force in Germany, CNBC.com, https://www.cnbc.com/id/38412190, July 26, 2010</ref> The International Monetary Fund issued a report in August 2010 saying that the measure succeeded only in impeding the markets. It said the ban "did relatively little to support the targeted institutions’ underlying stock prices, while liquidity dropped and volatility rose substantially." The IMF said there was no strong evidence that stock prices fell because of shorting.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-08-17/merkel-s-distortive-short-selling-ban-failed-to-achieve-aims-imf-says.html | work=Bloomberg | first=Rainer | last=Buergin | title=Merkel's 'Distortive' Short-Selling Ban Failed to Achieve Aims, IMF Says | date=August 17, 2010}}</ref>
In August 2011, France, Italy, Spain, Belgium and South Korea temporally banned all short selling in their financial stocks,<ref>{{citation |title= WRAPUP 7-Europe curbs short-selling as credit markets swoon |work= Reuters |author1=Geert de Clercq |author2=Paul Day |date= 11 August 2011 |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/08/12/europe-banks-idUSLDE77A05U20110812 }}</ref> while Germany pushed for an eurozone-wide ban on naked short selling.<ref>{{citation |title= Markets up on short-selling ban |date= 12 August 2012 |work= [[Irish Times]] |url= http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2011/0812/breaking67.html }}</ref>
==Regulatory enforcement actions== In 2005, the SEC notified [[Refco]] of intent to file an enforcement action against the securities unit of Refco for securities trading violations concerning the shorting of Sedona stock. The SEC sought information related to two former Refco brokers who handled the account of a client, Amro International, which shorted Sedona's stock.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2005/10/20/news/midcaps/refco/index.htm |title=More woes for Refco, execs: Newspapers say creditors eye over $1B insiders made from stock, while SEC probes "naked shorting"|date=October 20, 2005|publisher=CNN/Money | accessdate=May 19, 2010}}</ref> No charges had been filed by 2007.
In December 2006, the SEC sued Gryphon Partners, a [[hedge fund]], for [[insider trading]] and naked short-selling involving PIPEs in the unregistered stock of 35 companies. PIPEs are "private investments in public equities," used by companies to raise cash. The naked shorting took place in Canada, where it was legal at the time. Gryphon denied the charges.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/litigation/complaints/2006/comp19942.pdf |format=PDF|title=SEC Complaint against Gryphon Partners|date=December 12, 2006}}</ref>
In March 2007, [[Goldman Sachs]] was fined $2 million by the SEC for allowing customers to illegally sell shares short prior to secondary public offerings. Naked short-selling was allegedly used by the Goldman clients. The SEC charged Goldman with failing to ensure those clients had ownership of the shares. SEC Chairman Cox said "That is an important case and it reflects our interest in this area."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/law/corporate/article1519648.ece|title=Goldman Sachs fined $2m over short-selling|date=March 15, 2007|publisher=TimesOnline and AP | location=London | accessdate=May 19, 2010|first=Ben|last=Webster}}</ref>
In July 2007, [[Piper Jaffray]] was fined $150,000 by the [[New York Stock Exchange]] (NYSE). Piper violated securities trading rules from January through May 2005, selling shares without borrowing them, and also failing to "cover short sales in a timely manner", according to the NYSE.<ref>[https://www.nyse.com/DiscAxn/discAxn_07_2007.html "Monthly Disciplinary Actions – July 2007 "], ''NYSE Regulation'', July 11, 2007</ref> At the time of this fine, the NYSE had levied over $1.9 million in fines for naked short sales over seven regulatory actions.<ref>Edgar Ortega, [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=afpYSjiXF7iE "Piper Fined by the NYSE Over Short-Sale Violations"], ''Bloomberg News'', July 11, 2007</ref>
Also in July 2007, the [[American Stock Exchange]] fined two options market makers for violations of Regulation SHO. SBA Trading was sanctioned for $5 million, and ALA Trading was fined $3 million, which included disgorgement of profits. Both firms and their principals were suspended from association with the exchange for five years. The exchange said the firms used an exemption to Reg. SHO for options [[market makers]] to "impermissibly engage in naked short selling."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amex.com/atamex/regulation/discipline/2007/BArensteinALA_Decision_072007.pdf|title=NYSE: NYSE MKT|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amex.com/atamex/regulation/discipline/2007/SArensteinSBA_Decision_072007.pdf|title=NYSE: NYSE MKT|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amex.com/atamex/news/press/sn_regAA_073107.htm|title=NYSE: NYSE MKT|publisher=}}</ref>
In October 2007, the SEC settled charges against New York hedge fund adviser Sandell Asset Management Corp. and three executives of the firm for, among other things, shorting stock without locating shares to borrow. Fines totalling $8 million were imposed, and the firm neither admitted nor denied the charges.<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/news/press/2007/2007-216.htm "SEC Charges New York Hedge Fund Adviser With Short Sale Violations in Connection With Hibernia-Capital One Merger"], SEC Press Release, October 10, 2007</ref>
In October 2008 Lehman Brothers Inc. was fined $250,000 by the [[Financial Industry Regulatory Authority]] (FINRA) for failing to properly document the ownership of short sales as they occurred, and for failing to annotate an affirmative declaration that shares would be available by the settlement date.<ref>Heidi N. Moore, [https://blogs.wsj.com/deals/2008/10/22/we-see-dead-people-250k-regulatory-fine-for-lehman-short-sales/ "We See Dead People: $250K Fine for Lehman Short-Sales"], ''Wall Street Journal'', October 22, 2008</ref>
In April 2010 Goldman Sachs paid $450,000 to settle the SEC's allegations that it had failed to deliver "approximatedly" (sic) 86 short sells between early December 2008 and mid-January 2009, and that it had failed to institute adequate controls to prevent the failures. The company neither admitted nor denied any wrongdoing.<ref>Marcy Gordon (AP), [https://www.usatoday.com/money/industries/banking/2010-05-04-goldman-sachs-short-selling_N.htm Goldman Sachs settles short-sales allegations], ''USA Today'', 5 April 2010</ref>
In May 2013, lawyers acting for Goldman accidentally released an unredacted document revealing compromising internal discussions regarding naked short selling. e.g. "Fuck the compliance area – procedures, schmecedures,"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/blogs/taibblog/accidentally-released-and-incredibly-embarrassing-documents-show-how-goldman-et-al-engaged-in-naked-short-selling-20120515|title=Tabbi: Goldman and 'Naked Short Selling'|publisher=}}</ref>
==Litigation and DTCC== The [[Depository Trust and Clearing Corporation]] (DTCC) has been criticized by the Wall Street Journal for its approach to naked short selling.<ref name=WSJ_July2007/><ref>[http://www.dtcc.com/news/press/releases/2007/wsj_response.php?lpos=3&lid=3 "DTCC response to Wall Street Journal Article"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302054831/http://www.dtcc.com/news/press/releases/2007/wsj_response.php?lpos=3&lid=3 |date=2009-03-02 }}, Press release, July 6, 2007</ref> DTCC has been sued with regard to its alleged participation in naked short selling, and the issue of DTCC's possible involvement has been taken up by Senator [[Robert Foster Bennett|Robert Bennett]] and discussed by the NASAA and in articles in the [[Wall Street Journal]] and [[Euromoney]].<ref>[http://www.euromoney.com/Article/1001047/Naked-shorting-The-curious-incident-of-the-shares-that-didnt-.html "Naked shorting: The curious incident of the shares that didn't exist"], April 2005</ref> There is no dispute that illegal naked shorting happens;<ref name=WSJ_July2007/><ref>{{cite news | author = Kaja Whitehouse | title = Drop in naked shorts | work = [[New York Post]] | date = 2008-11-05 | url = http://www.nypost.com/seven/11052008/business/drop_in_naked_shorts_137107.htm | quote = In some cases, [naked short selling] may be perfectly legal, but usually it's not. (...) efforts to take more serious actions against short selling continued yesterday (...) }}</ref> what is in dispute is how much it happens, and to what extent is DTCC to blame.<ref name=WSJ_July2007/><ref>{{Cite web|author=James W. Christian, Robert Shapiro & John-Paul Whalen |year=2006 |title=Naked Short Selling: How Exposed Are Investors?|format= |work=Houston Law Review |url=http://www.houstonlawreview.org/archive/downloads/43-4_pdf/Christian.pdf|accessdate=2007-03-25}}</ref> Some companies with falling stocks blame DTCC as the keeper of the system where it happens, and say DTCC turns a blind eye to the problem.<ref name=WSJ_July2007/> Referring to trades that remain unsettled, DTCC's chief spokesman Stuart Goldstein said, "We're not saying there is no problem, but to suggest the sky is falling might be a bit overdone."<ref name=Bloomberg>{{cite news |accessdate = 2007-12-25 |url = http://www.rgm.com/articles/bloomberg2.html |title = Naked Short Sellers Hurt Companies With Stock They Don't Have |author = Drummond, Bob |date = August 4, 2006 |publisher = Bloomberg.com |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080106171438/http://www.rgm.com/articles/bloomberg2.html |archivedate = January 6, 2008 |df = }}</ref><ref name=FinancialWire>{{cite news |accessdate = 2007-12-25 |url = http://www.rgm.com/articles/financialwire.html |title = DTCC Chief Spokesperson Denies Existence of Lawsuit |date = May 11, 2004 |publisher = financialwire.net |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071105053113/http://www.rgm.com/articles/financialwire.html |archivedate = November 5, 2007 |df = }}</ref> In July 2007, Senator Bennett suggested on the [[U.S. Senate]] floor that the allegations involving DTCC and naked short selling are "serious enough" that there should be a hearing on them with DTCC officials by the [[Senate Banking Committee]], and that banking committee chairman Christopher Dodd has expressed a willingness to hold such a hearing.<ref>[http://bennett.senate.gov/press/record.cfm?id=279519 "Senator Bennett Discusses Naked Short Selling on the Senate Floor"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227192527/http://bennett.senate.gov/press/record.cfm?id=279519 |date=2008-02-27 }}, website of Senator Bennett, July 20, 2007, accessed 2009-02-21</ref>
Critics also contend DTCC has been too secretive with information about where naked shorting is taking place.<ref name=WSJ_July2007/> Ten suits concerning naked short-selling filed against the DTCC were withdrawn or dismissed by May 2005.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Nevada Court Dismisses Nanopierce Lawsuit Against DTCC On Naked Short Selling |publisher=Depository Trust Clearing Corporation |url=http://www.dtcc.com/Publications/dtcc/may05/nanopierce.html |date=May 2005 |accessdate=2007-02-05 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061207091029/http://www.dtcc.com/Publications/dtcc/may05/nanopierce.html |archivedate = December 7, 2006}}</ref>
A suit by Electronic Trading Group, naming major Wall Street brokerages, was filed in April 2006 and dismissed in December 2007.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/business/2006/04/13/naked-shorts-lawsuit-cx_lm_0413naked.html |title=Naked Shorts |publisher=[[Forbes]] |first=Liz |last=Moyer |date=2006-04-13 |accessdate=2007-10-10}}</ref><ref>[http://money.cnn.com/news/newsfeeds/articles/djf500/200712201132DOWJONESDJONLINE000859_FORTUNE5.htm "US Judge Dismisses Naked Short Selling Suit Vs. Brokers"], ''Dow Jones News Service'', Dec. 20, 2007</ref>
Two separate lawsuits, filed in 2006 and 2007 by [[NovaStar Financial, Inc.]] shareholders and [[Overstock.com]], named as defendants ten Wall Street prime brokers. They claimed a scheme to manipulate the companies' stock by allowing naked short selling.<ref>{{cite news |title=Naked Short Victim Strikes Back |url=https://www.forbes.com/2007/02/02/naked-short-suit-overstock-biz-cx_lm_0202naked.html |date=February 2, 2007 |work=Forbes|accessdate=2007-10-10 }}</ref> A motion to dismiss the Overstock suit was denied in July 2007.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/wallstreet/2007/07/18/naked-shorting-overstock-biz-wallst-cx_lm_0718overstock.html |title=Naked Shorting Case Gains Traction|date=July 18, 2007|author=Liz Moyer |work=Forbes}}</ref><ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=conewsstory&refer=conews&tkr=OSTK:US&sid=aPgnC8667Qbo "Overstock Shares Rise on Court Ruling in Broker Suit"], ''Bloomberg News'', July 18, 2007</ref>
A suit against DTCC by Pet Quarters Inc. was dismissed by a federal court in Arkansas, and upheld by the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals in March 2009.<ref>''Pet Quarters, Inc. v. Depository Trust and Clearing Corp.'' --- F.3d ----, 2009 WL 579270 C.A.8 (Ark.),2009.</ref> Pet Quarters alleged the Depository Trust & Clearing Corp.'s stock-borrow program resulted in the creation of nonexistent or [[phantom stock]] and contributed to the illegal short selling of the company's shares. The court ruled: "In short, all the damages that Pet Quarters claims to have suffered stem from activities performed or statements made by the defendants in conformity with the program's Commission approved rules. We conclude that the district court did not err in dismissing the complaint on the basis of preemption." Pet Quarters' complaint was almost identical to suits against DTCC brought by Whistler Investments Inc. and Nanopierce Technologies Inc. The suits also challenged DTCC's stock-borrow program, and were dismissed.<ref>"Court Rules Against Company Claiming Illegal Short Selling" by Carol Remond, Dow Jones News Service, March 11, 2009</ref>
==Studies== A study of trading in initial public offerings by two SEC staff economists, published in April 2007, found that excessive numbers of fails to deliver were not correlated with naked short selling. The authors of the study said that while the findings in the paper specifically concern IPO trading, "The results presented in this paper also inform a public debate surrounding the role of short selling and fails to deliver in price formation."<ref>{{Cite web|ssrn=981242 |title=Short Selling and Failures to Deliver in Initial Public Offerings |author1=Amy K. Edwards |author2=Kathleen Weiss Hanley |lastauthoramp=yes |date=April 18, 2007}}</ref>
In contrast, a study by Leslie Boni in 2004 found correlation between "strategic delivery failures" and the cost of borrowing shares. The paper, which looked at a "unique dataset of the entire cross-section of U.S. equities," credited the initial recognition of strategic delivery fails to Richard Evans, Chris Geczy, David Musto and Adam Reed, and found its review to provide evidence consistent with their hypothesis that "market makers strategically fail to deliver shares when borrowing costs are high." A recent study by Autore, Boulton, and Braga-Alves examines stock returns around delivery failures between 2005 and 2008 and finds evidence consistent with a positive link between delivery failures and borrowing costs.
An April 2007 study conducted for Canadian market regulators by Market Regulation Services Inc. found that fails to deliver securities were not a significant problem on the Canadian market, that "less than 6% of fails resulting from the sale of a security involved short sales" and that "fails involving short sales are projected to account for only 0.07% of total short sales.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://investmentexecutive.com/client/en/News/DetailNews.asp?Id=38819&cat=8&IdSection=8&PageMem=&nbNews=&IdPub=|title=No evidence of excessive failed trades on Canadian marketplaces: study |author=James Langton|work=Investment Executive|date=April 15, 2007}}</ref>
A Government Accountability Office study, released in June 2009, found that recent SEC rules had apparently reduced abusive short selling, but that the SEC needed to give clearer guidance to the brokerage industry.<ref name='AP-6-3-09'>{{cite news | first=Marcy | last=Gordon | title=Guidance on short-selling needed: GAO | date=2009-06-03 | publisher= | work =Associated Press | pages = | language = }}</ref>
The [[Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission]], appointed by Congress to investigate the 2008 financial crisis, makes no reference to naked shorting, or short-selling of financial stocks, in its conclusions.<ref>http://fcic-static.law.stanford.edu/cdn_media/fcic-reports/fcic_final_report_conclusions.pdf</ref>
A study of fails to deliver, published in the Journal of Financial Economics in 2014, found no evidence that FTDs "caused price distortions or the failure of financial firms during the 2008 financial crisis." Researchers studied 1,492 New York Stock Exchange stocks over a 42-month period from 2005 to 2008, and found that "greater FTDs lead to higher liquidity and pricing efficiency, and their impact is similar to our estimate of delivered short sales."<ref name="sciencedirect.com"/><ref> http://www.cityam.com/1407505403/what-caused-2008-financial-crisis-not-short-selling-it-turns-out</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buffalo.edu/news/releases/2014/07/042.html|title=Short sellers not to blame for 2008 financial crisis, study finds - University at Buffalo|publisher=}}</ref>
==Media coverage== Some journalists have expressed concern about naked short selling, while others contend that naked short selling is not harmful and that its prevalence has been exaggerated by corporate officials seeking to blame external forces for internal problems with their companies.<ref name="nudists"> {{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB114480254610823574 |title=Do Nudists Run Wall Street? |publisher=Wall Street Journal |date=April 12, 2006 |accessdate=2008-03-16 |last=Holman |first=Jenkins }}</ref> Others have discussed naked short selling as a confusing or bizarre form of trading.<ref>Alex Blumberg (editor),[https://www.npr.org/blogs/money/2008/09/catch_it_this_weekend_naked_sh.html "Catch It This Weekend: 'Naked Short Selling'"], NPR, September 12, 2006</ref>
In June 2007, executives of [[Universal Express]], which had claimed naked shorting of its stock, were sanctioned by a federal court judge for violation of securities laws.<ref>{{cite news |title=S.E.C. Requests Receiver for Universal Express |work=The New York Times |date=June 23, 2007 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/23/business/23sec.html | first=Floyd | last=Norris | accessdate=May 19, 2010}}</ref> Referring to a court ruling against CEO Richard Altomare, [[New York Times]] columnist [[Floyd Norris]] said: "In Altomare's view, the issues that bothered the judge are irrelevant. Long and short of it, this is a naked short hallmark case in the making. Or it is proof that it can take a long time for the SEC to stop a fraud."<ref>Floyd Norris, [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/22/business/22norris.html "A Sad Tale of Fictional SEC Filings"], ''The New York Times'', June 22, 2007</ref> Universal Express claimed that 6,000 small companies had been put out of business by naked shorting, which the company said "the SEC has ignored and condoned."<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090325160232/http://www.usxp.com/newyorktime.pdf "Universal Express statement" (pdf)], June 28, 2007 (archived 2009)</ref>
Reviewing the SEC's July 2008 emergency order, ''[[Barron's Magazine|Barron's]]'' said in an editorial: "Rather than fixing any of the real problems with the agency and its mission, Cox and his fellow commissioners waved a newspaper and swatted the imaginary fly of naked short-selling. It made a big noise, but there's no dead bug."<ref name='Donlan'>{{cite news |url=http://online.barrons.com/article/SB121702597332186163.html?mod=googlenews_barrons |date=July 28, 2008|title= Swatting an Imaginary Fly |author=Thomas G. Donlan |work=Barron's Magazine }}</ref> Holman Jenkins of the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' said the order was "an exercise in symbolic confidence-building" and that naked shorting involved technical concerns except for subscribers to a "devil theory".<ref name='Bankinvestors'>{{cite news | first=Holman | last=Jenkins | title=Washiogton (heart) Bank Investors | date=2008-07-23 | publisher= | work =The Wall Street Journal | pages = | language = }}</ref> ''[[The Economist]]'' said the SEC had "picked the wrong target", mentioning a study by [[Arturo Bris]] of the Swiss [[International Institute for Management Development]] who found that trading in the 19 financial stocks became less efficient.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.economist.com/finance/displaystory.cfm?story_id=11921720 | work=The Economist | title=Phantom menace | date=August 14, 2008}}</ref> The Washington Post expressed approval of the SEC's decision to address a "frenetic shadow world of postponed promises, borrowed time, obscured paperwork and nail-biting price-watching, usually compressed into a few high-tension days swirling around the decline of a company."<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/07/15/AR2008071502829.html | work=The Washington Post | title='Naked Shorting': Far More Dangerous Than Sexy | date=July 16, 2008 | accessdate=May 19, 2010}}</ref> The Los Angeles Times called the practice of naked short selling "hard to defend," and stated that it was past time the SEC became active in addressing market manipulation.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/classified/realestate/news/la-ed-sec17-2008jul17,0,5572972.story | work=Los Angeles Times | title=SEC muscle, finally | accessdate=May 19, 2010 | date=July 17, 2008}}</ref>
The Wall Street Journal said in an editorial in July 2008 that "the Beltway is shooting the messenger by questioning the price-setting mechanisms for barrels of oil and shares of stock." But it said the emergency order to bar naked short selling "won't do much harm," and said "Critics might say it's a solution to a nonproblem, but the SEC doesn't claim to be solving a problem. The Commission's move is intended to prevent even the possibility that an unscrupulous short seller could drive down the shares of a financial firm with a flood of sell orders that aren't backed by an actual ability to deliver the shares to buyers."<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB121633656801263789?mod=opinion_main_review_and_outlooks | work=The Wall Street Journal | title=Who's Partying Naked? | date=July 18, 2008}}</ref>
In an article in March 2009 Bloomberg News Service said that the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy may have been prevented by curbs on naked shorting. "..as many as 32.8 million shares in the company were sold and not delivered to buyers on time as of Sept. 11, according to data compiled by the Securities and Exchange Commission.."<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aB1jlqmFOTCA | work=Bloomberg | title=Naked Short Sales Hint Fraud in Bringing Down Lehman (Update1) | date=March 19, 2009}}</ref>
In May 2009, the New York Times's chief financial correspondent [[Floyd Norris]] reported that naked shorting is "almost gone." He said that delivery failures, where they occur, are quickly corrected.<ref name='Norris5-1-09'>{{cite news | first=Floyd | last=Norris |authorlink= Floyd Norris | title=Goodbye to Naked Shorting | date=2009-05-01 | publisher= | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/01/business/economy/01norris.html | work =The New York Times | pages = | accessdate = 2009-05-01 | language = }}</ref>
In an article published in October 2009, [[Rolling Stone]] writer [[Matt Taibbi]] contended that [[Bear Stearns]] and [[Lehman Brothers]] were flooded with "counterfeit stock" that helped kill both companies. Taibbi said that the two firms got a "push" into extinction from "a flat-out counterfeiting scheme called naked short-selling".<ref name='Taibbi'>{{cite news | first=Matt | last=Taibbi |authorlink= Matt Taibbi | title=Wall Street's Naked Swindle | date=October 2009 | publisher= | url =https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/story/30481512/wall_streets_naked_swindle | work =Rolling Stone | pages = 50–59| accessdate = 2009-10-15 | language = }}Cf. p.53: "But the most damning thing the attack on Bear had in common with these earlier manipulations was the employment of a type of counterfeiting scheme called naked short-selling. From the moment the confidential meeting at the Fed ended on March 11th, Bear became the target of this ostensibly illegal practice – and the companies widely rumored to be behind the assault were in that room."</ref> During a May 2010 discussion on the inclusion of 'counterfeiting' in the charges filed against Icelandic bankers, the host [[Max Keiser]] speculated that the charge might refer to naked short selling because "naked short-selling is the same as counterfeiting, in that it is selling something that doesn't exist."<ref>{{cite news| url=https://archive.org/details/MaxKeiserRadio-TheTruthAboutMarkets-15May2010 |title=Max Keiser, Truth About Markets, May 15, 2010, minute 12.15}}</ref> A 2014 study of fails to deliver, published in the Journal of Financial Economics, which found no evidence that fails contributed to "price distortions or the failure of financial firms during the 2008 financial crisis."<ref name="sciencedirect.com"/>

{{refimprove|date=January 2010}} The '''National Apartment Association''' ('''NAA''') is a non-profit [[trade association]] of [[apartment]] communities, owners and suppliers. These member companies are also part of NAA with their membership at the local level. Members represent the various facets of the multifamily housing industry: apartment owners, [[management]] executives, developers, builders, investors, [[property manager]]s, [[leasing]] consultants, maintenance personnel, suppliers and related business professionals throughout the United States and Canada. NAA has its headquarters in [[Arlington County, Virginia|Arlington]], VA.
NAA also publishes a [[trade magazine]], ''UNITS''.
== National Apartment Association Education Institute (NAAEI) == That National Apartment Association also provides education courses and [[certification]]s for professionals in the apartment industry. The National Apartment Association Education Institute (NAAEI) offers these courses. NAAEI is the education arm of NAA. Its mission is to provide broad-based education, training and recruitment programs that attract, nurture and retain high-quality professionals and develop tomorrow's apartment industry leaders.http://www.naahq.org/learn/education/naa-education-institute * '''Certified Apartment Manager (CAM):''' Course training covers [[management]] of residential issues, legal responsibilities, [[human resource management]], [[fair housing]], [[marketing]], [[property maintenance]] for managers, [[risk management]] and [[fiscal management]]. * '''Certified Apartment Portfolio Supervisor (CAPS)''': An in-depth review of [[property management]] principles and techniques as used by the professional supervisor. * '''Certificate for Apartment Maintenance Technicians (CAMT):''' An introduction for new maintenance professionals or as a refresher for the veteran employee, to give these professionals the knowledge and tools necessary to run an effective maintenance program. *''' Independent Rental Owner Professional Designation Course (IROP):''' A course offered to the rental owner who manages their personally-held [[Multi-family residential|multifamily property]] or properties. The independent rental owner serves several roles in property management, [[public relations]] specialist, administrator, [[chief financial officer]], [[marketing director]] and [[operations manager]]. *''' National Apartment Leasing Professional (NALP)''': A course offered to leasing professionals to improve critical skills in effective [[marketing strategy]], qualifying prospective residents, closing sales, preparing and executing [[lease agreement]]s, responding to resident issues and understanding the lease renewal process. == Apartment Career Promotion == As part of NAAEI's mission to promote careers in the apartment industry, February is designated as annual National Apartment Careers Month. National Apartment Careers Month was created to bring awareness about career opportunities in the industry.http://www.apartmentcareers.com/77-uncategorised/150-national-apartment-careers-month-february-2014 == Military Spouse and Veteran Outreach == NAAEI hosted the first ever Military Career fair in San Diego, CA on June 19, 2013.{{cite web |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/military-career-fair-connects-san-183000356.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-01-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140522222630/http://finance.yahoo.com/news/military-career-fair-connects-san-183000356.html |archivedate=2014-05-22 |df= }} The [[career fair]] was for transitioning military and military spouses to meet with apartment industry employers, interview for jobs and learn more about apartment careers.{{cite web |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/military-career-fair-connects-san-183000356.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-01-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140522222630/http://finance.yahoo.com/news/military-career-fair-connects-san-183000356.html |archivedate=2014-05-22 |df= }} == Economic Impact == In 2013, the National Apartment Association partnered with the National Multifamily Housing Council to release the first study, "The Trillion Dollar Industry" that quantifies the gross domestic product of the multifamily housing industry.http://www.multifamilyexecutive.com/multifamily/multifamily-a-trillion-dollar-business.aspx?rssLink=Multifamily%20a%20Trillion%20Dollar%20Business This study found that apartment industry spending contributes $1.1 trillion to the national economy and supports 25.4 million jobs.http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/real_estate/2013/02/apartment-demand-fueling-construction.html?page=all This report serves as the first component of a large-scale, multi-media campaign aimed at confronting some of the political and social biases against apartments.{{cite web |url=http://www.nmhc.org/Content.cfm?ItemNumber=61083 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-12-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206144447/http://www.nmhc.org/Content.cfm?ItemNumber=61083 |archivedate=2013-12-06 |df= }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.naahq.org/ Official website] [[Category:Business organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Real estate-related professional associations]] *[https://www.kalyandevelopers.com/blog/complete-guide-apartment-owners-association Apartment Owners Association]

{{Use American English|date=July 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} '''Naval Nuclear Propulsion Information (NNPI)''' is a category of [[intellectual capital]] defined by the [[United States Navy]] to be "classified or unclassified information concerning the design, arrangement, development, manufacture, testing, operation, administration, training, maintenance, and repair of the propulsion plants of naval nuclear-powered ships and prototypes, including the associated shipboard and shore-based nuclear support facilities.." <ref>{{cite web |url=http://doni.daps.dla.mil/Directives/09000%20General%20Ship%20Design%20and%20Support/09-200%20Propulsion%20Plants%20Support/N9210.3%20(Unclas%20Portion).pdf |title=OPNAVINST N9210.3, SAFEGUARDING OF NAVAL NUCLEAR PROPULSION INFORMATION (NNPI), 6/7/2010, Unclassified Portion, page 1-1, Definition|accessdate=February 2012}}</ref>
Not all NNPI is [[classified information]]. While most NNPI is sensitive, the Navy recognizes that the public has an interest in [[Natural environment|environmental]], [[safety]], and [[health]] information, and that the basic [[research]] carried out by the Navy can be useful to [[industry]]. Unclassified information is therefore marked with the acronym "U-NNPI", but is still restricted as [[wikt:NOFORN|NOFORN]].<ref>See OPNAVINST N9210.3, esp. Chapters 3 and 4.</ref>
NNPI is explicitly protected information and is not released to the general public without authority. Those who release even NNPI-U without authority may be administratively punished, and even [[criminal law|criminally]] in the case of NNPI-C.{{Citation needed|date=April 2007}} NNPI is restricted from disclosure under the Arms Export Control Act, [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/22/2778 22 USC §§2778] and [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/22/2794 2794(7)]; such information is listed in the [http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr;sid=d148ef6a9390b1e27fc09865c734666c;rgn=div5;view=text;node=22%3A1.0.1.13.60;idno=22;cc=ecfr US Munitions List, 22 CFR §121.1], Category VI, paragraph (g).
In some instances, small events that would normally be reported as "Events" or LOC (Loss of Control) to the [[Nuclear Regulatory Commission]] from other licensees can be classified as NNPI-C.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://azstarnet.com/news/national/dangerous-tennessee-radioactive-spill-kept-from-public-papers-sealed/article_70fed1e3-e100-5f8e-91b6-4535b39289d6.html |title=Dangerous Tennessee radioactive spill kept from public; papers sealed |author=Associated Press |publisher=Arizona Daily Star |date=2007-08-21 }}</ref> This designation differs for similar "events" that occur on a secret network, which are referred to as "spillage".
==References== {{more footnotes|date=May 2008}} <references/>
* OPNAVINST N9210.3, SAFEGUARDING OF NAVAL NUCLEAR PROPULSION INFORMATION (NNPI), 6/7/2010

{{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox person | image = niall.jpg | caption = Niall Donnelly | birth_place = [[Navan]], County Meath, Ireland | occupation = Entrepreneur | spouse = [[Kelly Beckett]] }}
'''Niall Donnelly''' is an Irish entrepreneur based in Los Angeles, California. He is known for Technology and Entertainment companies in Los Angeles and London has built a name for himself both sides of the Atlantic as a major force in the entertainment and technology industry.
==Early life and education== Niall was born in [[Mullagh, County Cavan]] and grew up in [[Navan]], in [[County Meath]], Ireland. He attended [[St. Patrick's Classical School]] in Navan, and went on to earn a degree in [[Geography]] and Politics at [[University College Dublin]], where he served as the youngest ever Entertainments Officer in the history of UCD. He started his first business at age twelve, a tennis academy that earned him £30 per week.<ref>The Irish Post, "In Profile: Entrepreneur Niall Donnelly", December 2, 2009</ref>
==Career== Donnelly began his entrepreneurial career in real estate, buying and selling properties and converting houses into flats. In 2005, Donnelly purchased a building on London's Chapel Market and converted it into Anam Cocktail Lounge. Gaelic for "Life & Soul" Anam was nominated for the Time Out Best Bar Award in 2005<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.tcm.ie/irishpost/2005/08/17/story3066.asp|title=Anam: The coolest Irish bar in London|date=17 August 2005|work=The Irish Post}}</ref> and also The Evening Standard Bar of the Year Award in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|author=Campion, Charles|url=http://archives.tcm.ie/irishpost/2005/08/17/story3066.asp|title=Vote for your favorite drinking den|date=8 March 2008|work=London Evening Standard}}</ref> From this he went on to build a group of successful Rock n Roll bars and entertainment venues in the London area.
In addition to his bar and nightclub ventures, Donnelly has a number of investments and ventures in Entertainment, Media, Live Events & Festivals and Television in the UK and United States under his holding company Mad in the USA LLC, formerly Arrogant LLC.<ref>{{cite web|author=Roberts, Randall|url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/westcoastsound/news/rolling-stone-magazine-to-open/|title=Rolling Stone Magazine to Open Hollywood Club/Restaurant in the Summer of 2010 (?!)|date=4 December 2009|publisher=LaWeekly.com}}</ref> In 2008, Niall acquired streaming video website [[Newsplayer]], along with business partner Brendan Morrissey. The site provides web access to historical news footage, including the onscreen interview archives of former [[Newsplayer]] Chairman of the board [[Sir David Frost]].<ref>[[Newsplayer]] ([[Newsplayer]])</ref> In January 2009 The Irish Entrepreneur and The Irish Times called Donnelly one of the top 10 "Irish Entrepreneurs to Watch" worldwide, citing his creativity and record of success both sides of The Atlantic.<ref>"100 Greatest Self-Made Irish Entrepreneurs", ''Irish Entrepreneur'', Volume 8, Issue 1, January 2009</ref>
In Feb 2011 Donnelly opened the first-ever US ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine venue at the [[Hollywood and Highland]] Complex in Hollywood, CA. Rolling Stone LA is a multi-level space encompassing more than {{convert|10000|sqft|m2}} in a blend of equal parts restaurant, bar, lounge and upscale private-event space.<ref>{{cite web|author=Burke, Roisin|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/irish/builder-ready-to-roll-with-rolling-stone-1973125.html|title=Builder ready to roll with Rolling Stone|date=13 December 2009|work=The Irish Independent}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Vincent, Roger|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/dec/04/business/la-fi-rolling-stone4-2009dec04|title=Rolling Stone to launch restaurant chain in L.A.|date=4 December 2009|work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref>
Donnelly launched the first online nightlife reservation business Bevvy.com in 2011<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2011/01/12/prweb4963334.DTL|title=Rolling Stone LA Founder Launches Group Buying Website Bevvy.com for the Nightlife and Beverage Industry|date=12 January 2011|work=The San Francisco Chronicle}}</ref> and he was nominated in the "Top five Irish Entrepreneurs" by Smarta.com the same year.<ref>{{cite web|author=Rebecca|url=http://smarta.com/blog/2011/3/st-patricks-day-special-the-top-five-irish-entrepreneurs|title=ST. PATRICKS DAY SPECIAL: The Top 5 Irish Entrepreneurs|date=17 March 2011|publisher=Smarta.com}}</ref> Bevvy was named in the "Top 100 Brilliant Companies in the US" by Entrepreneur Magazine in June issue 2011.<ref>{{cite web|author=Amy Cosper|url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/219670 |title=Top 100 Brilliant Companies in the US|date=June 2011|work=Entrepreneur Magazine}}</ref> In Sep 2012 Donnelly was named by the ITLG in the "Hollywood 50", honouring the most influential Irish or Irish American entertainment and technology executives in Hollywood.<ref>{{cite web|author=ITLG|url=http://www.itlg.org/events/2012-innovation-in-entertainment/hollywood-50.php |title=The Top 50 Irish Executives in Hollywood|date=September 2012|publisher=ITLG}}</ref>
In 2013 Donnelly launched the All-'Merican Festival Fustercluck in [[Temecula]], California. Fustercluck is described as a 5k adventure full of hilarious Hillbillies and Hipsters followed by an epic hoedown where many of the fellers from [[Deliverance]] and [[Duck Dynasty]] make an appearance. The first event featured a 5k adventure through wild [[Southern California]] forests being chased by crazed hillbillies, followed by a fun [[Redneck Games]] competition and festival featuring the Honky Tonk Hubcap Hurl, Bobbin' For Pigs Feet, Cornhole, Redneck Horseshoes, Mud Belly Flop Contest, White Trash Beer Pong, BBQ Cook Off, Live Americana, Bluegrass and Country Bands. It was billed as the most All-'Merican event in 'Merica.
In 2015 Donnelly co-founded Innovate Labs LLC. Innovate's main product Lantern is bringing the open internet to millions worldwide.
